subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: One general rule that straightens out these problems is as follows: Spell the word in QS as if you were pronouncing the word formally, i.e. by itself alone,
messageBody:
One general rule that straightens out these
problems is as follows: Spell the word in QS as if you
were pronouncing the word formally, i.e. by itself
alone, with no other words around it.

While this may not cause an inherently better
spelling, it does cause a more consistent one.

I seem to pronounce the verb with TOT and the noun
with CHURCH. Perhaps a harking back to childhood with
Choo-choo?

--- Gregory Weidman <delrayva@...> wrote:
> writing. My family and I discussed recently the
> different pronunciations of the "t" in "train" that
> we have among us. The difference is that sometimes
> TOT is used, and sometimes CHURCH is used.

===========
Never insult anyone by accident.
- Robert A. Heinlein

   One general rule that straightens out these
problems is as follows: Spell the word in QS as if you
were pronouncing the word formally, i.e. by itself
alone, with no other words around it.

   While this may not cause an inherently better
spelling, it does cause a more consistent one.

   I seem to pronounce the verb with TOT and the noun
with CHURCH. Perhaps a harking back to childhood with
Choo-choo?

--- Gregory Weidman <delrayva@...> wrote:
> writing.  My family and I discussed recently the
> different pronunciations  of the "t" in "train" that
> we have among us.  The difference is that sometimes
> TOT is used, and sometimes CHURCH is used.
